title: Banking & Credit
description: Navigate banking and build good credit

content.introduction: Understanding banking services is crucial for managing your money effectively. This lesson covers the types of accounts, services, and how to choose the right bank for your needs.

content.subtitle: Checking Accounts
content.text: For daily transactions, paying bills, and accessing cash.
list: Features: Debit card, checks, online bill pay.
Consider: Monthly fees, minimum balance, ATM access.

content.subtitle: Savings Accounts
content.text: For setting aside money for future goals and emergencies.
list: Consider: Interest rates (APY), withdrawal limits, fees.

content.subtitle: Traditional Banks vs. Credit Unions vs. Online Banks
content.text: Compare options based on your priorities:
list: Traditional Banks: Wide range of services, many branches/ATMs.
Credit Unions: Non-profit, member-owned, often better rates and lower fees.
Online Banks: Higher interest rates, lower fees, but no physical branches.

keyTakeaways: Choose bank accounts that align with your financial habits and goals.
Compare fees, interest rates, and services before opening an account.
Online banking and mobile apps offer convenience for managing your money.
nextSteps: Review your current bank accounts and their features.
Research different banking options if you're considering a switch.
Set up online access and mobile banking for your accounts.

content.introduction: Your credit score is a vital number that impacts your ability to borrow money, rent an apartment, and even get a job. This lesson explains what credit scores are, how they're calculated, and why they matter.

content.subtitle: Definition and Importance
content.text: A three-digit number (typically 300-850) that lenders use to assess your creditworthiness. Higher scores mean lower risk and better loan terms.

content.subtitle: Factors Affecting Your Score
content.text: The main components of your FICO score:
list: Payment History (35%): Paying bills on time is most important.
Amounts Owed (30%): How much debt you carry relative to your credit limits (credit utilization).
Length of Credit History (15%): How long you've had credit accounts.
New Credit (10%): Recently opened accounts and credit inquiries.
Credit Mix (10%): Variety of credit types (cards, loans, mortgage).

keyTakeaways: A good credit score is essential for financial health.
Paying bills on time and keeping credit utilization low are key to a good score.
Regularly check your credit report for errors.
nextSteps: Check your credit score for free from reputable sources.
Review your credit report for any inaccuracies.
Identify one action you can take to improve or maintain your credit score.

content.introduction: Credit cards can be powerful financial tools or dangerous debt traps. This lesson explores the advantages and disadvantages of using credit cards.

content.subtitle: Building Credit History
content.text: Responsible use helps build a positive credit score.

content.subtitle: Convenience and Security
content.text: Safer than cash for online purchases, fraud protection.

content.subtitle: Rewards and Perks
content.text: Cash back, travel points, discounts.

content.subtitle: High Interest Rates
content.text: Carrying a balance can lead to significant debt due to interest.

content.subtitle: Fees
content.text: Annual fees, late payment fees, over-limit fees.

content.subtitle: Temptation to Overspend
content.text: Easy to spend more than you can afford.

keyTakeaways: Credit cards offer benefits like building credit and rewards, but come with risks.
Always pay your balance in full each month to avoid interest charges.
Choose credit cards that match your spending habits and financial goals.
nextSteps: If you have a credit card, review its terms, interest rate, and fees.
Consider a secured credit card if you're new to credit.
Set up automatic payments to avoid missing due dates.

content.introduction: Debt is a part of modern financial life, but it needs to be managed carefully. This lesson covers strategies for responsible debt management and avoiding debt traps.

content.subtitle: Good Debt
content.text: Investments that can increase your net worth or future income (e.g., student loans for education, mortgages).

content.subtitle: Bad Debt
content.text: Debt for depreciating assets or consumption (e.g., high-interest credit card debt for non-essentials).

content.subtitle: Debt Snowball Method
content.text: Pay off smallest debts first for psychological wins, then roll payments to larger debts.

content.subtitle: Debt Avalanche Method
content.text: Pay off debts with the highest interest rates first to save money on interest.

keyTakeaways: Not all debt is bad, but all debt requires careful management.
Prioritize paying off high-interest debt quickly.
Create a budget that includes debt repayment.
nextSteps: List all your debts, including interest rates and minimum payments.
Choose a debt repayment strategy (snowball or avalanche).
Explore options like balance transfers or consolidation if you have high-interest debt.

content.introduction: Building a good credit history as a student sets you up for financial success after graduation. This lesson provides practical tips for establishing and building credit responsibly.

content.subtitle: Secured Credit Card
content.text: Requires a security deposit that usually becomes your credit limit. Good for beginners.

content.subtitle: Student Credit Card
content.text: Designed for students, often with lower credit limits and easier approval.

content.subtitle: Authorized User Status
content.text: Being added to a parent's or guardian's credit card account (if they have good credit).

content.subtitle: Credit Builder Loans
content.text: Small loans where payments are reported to credit bureaus.

keyTakeaways: Start building credit early and responsibly as a student.
Use credit sparingly and always pay on time.
nextSteps: Research student or secured credit card options.
Discuss becoming an authorized user with a trusted family member.
Make small, regular purchases on your credit card and pay them off in full.

content.introduction: Your credit report is a detailed history of your credit activity. Understanding and monitoring it is key to maintaining good credit. This lesson explains how to read your report and why monitoring is important.

content.subtitle: Key Sections
content.text: Personal information, credit accounts, public records, inquiries.

content.subtitle: How to Get Your Report
content.text: You're entitled to one free report annually from each of the three major bureaus (Equifax, Experian, TransUnion) via AnnualCreditReport.com.

content.subtitle: Detecting Errors
content.text: Mistakes can negatively impact your score. Dispute any inaccuracies.

content.subtitle: Identifying Identity Theft
content.text: Unauthorized accounts or activity can be signs of fraud.

keyTakeaways: Regularly review your credit report from all three major bureaus.
Dispute any errors you find immediately.
Monitoring helps protect against identity theft and maintain a healthy credit score.
nextSteps: Request your free annual credit reports.
Carefully review each report for accuracy.
Consider using a credit monitoring service (some are free).
